item.title: The Development of the C Language (cm.bell-labs.co)
item.description: 'The Development and Evolution of the C Programming Language'
item.content:encoded:
This paper discusses the development of the C programming language, its influences, and the conditions under which it was created. It highlights the evolution of C from its parent language BCPL and its grandparent language BCPL. The paper also mentions the significant periods of changes in the language and its association with the Unix operating system. It concludes by noting that C has become one of the dominant languages in the computer industry today.

4 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Julia and Mojo (Modular) Mandelbrot Benchmark (discourse.julialang.org)
item.description: Optimizing Julia Code for Mandelbrot Set Calculation
item.content:encoded:
Julia code for calculating the Mandelbrot set is benchmarked against Mojo code. The Julia code takes 7.45 ms to run, while the Mojo code runs in 2.14 ms. Suggestions are made to improve the Julia code, such as using SIMD vectorization and decomposing complex numbers. The @simd macro is limited and cannot see through function calls. Differences between the Julia and Mojo code, such as the use of FP ranges, may also affect performance. Overall, the goal is to optimize the Julia code and potentially surpass the performance of the Mojo code.

84 Points | 37 comments

item.title: Newly discovered comet Nishimura could be visible to naked eye this weekend (www.theguardian.com)
item.description: Newly Discovered Comet Nishimura Could Be Visible to Naked Eye This Weekend
item.content:encoded:
Comet Nishimura, discovered just a month ago, could be visible to the naked eye this weekend, offering stargazers a rare opportunity. Most comets are discovered months or years before reaching peak visibility, but Nishimura is an exception. It swings by the sun every 437 years and spends most of its time in the outer solar system. The comet will pass closest to the sun on September 17th and will be easiest to observe in the northern hemisphere this Saturday and Sunday. Stargazers can look towards the north-eastern sky before sunrise, to the left of Venus, for the best view.

100 Points | 45 comments

item.title: Advanced NLP with SpaCy (course.spacy.io)
item.description: Mastering Natural Language Processing with spaCy
item.content:encoded:
This course on spaCy, a Python library for Natural Language Processing, covers the basics of text processing, large-scale data analysis, processing pipelines, and training neural network models. It teaches you how to extract specific information from text, combine statistical and rule-based approaches, customize spaCy's models, and build advanced natural language understanding systems. The course is free and interactive, and is taught by Ines, one of the core developers of spaCy. She specializes in modern developer tools for AI, Machine Learning, and NLP.

23 Points | 12 comments

item.title: Decoded: GNU Coreutils (2018) (maizure.org)
item.description: Decoding GNU coreutils: A Comprehensive Exploration of Command-Line Utilities
item.content:encoded:
Decoding GNU coreutils is a long-term project that aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the design and implementation of the command-line utilities in version 8.3. It is a valuable resource for novice programmers looking to explore the inner workings of these utilities. The project is divided into phases, with the first two phases already completed, focusing on providing an overview of each utility and discussing important design decisions. The project also covers the basic design patterns shared by most utilities, such as utility initialization, parsing with Getopt, traversing the file system with fts, and using syscall wrappers and helpers. The coreutils codebase is characterized by its simplicity, use of macros, and reliance on POSIX standards. Overall, this project offers valuable insights into the GNU coreutils and their implementation.

219 Points | 64 comments

item.title: The Mind-Bending Math Behind Spot It (2018) (www.smithsonianmag.com)
item.description: 'Spot It!' Card Game: The Math Behind the Matching Symbols
item.content:encoded:
Spot It!, the popular family card game, is based on complex mathematics. The game's structure, where every card has one matching symbol with any other card, is rooted in the logic puzzles of 19th-century mathematicians. The game's origins can be traced back to the Reverend Thomas Penyngton Kirkman's Schoolgirl Problem, a question of combinatorics. The general solution to this problem was not figured out until 1968, and it has since found applications in various fields, including card games like Spot It!

6 Points | 1 comments

item.title: Embeddable Common Lisp 23.9.9 (ecl.common-lisp.dev)
item.description: 'Embeddable Common-Lisp 23.9.9 Released with Bug Fixes and New Features'
item.content:encoded:
The ECL developers have announced the release of ECL 23.9.9, a stable version of Embeddable Common-Lisp. This release includes bug fixes, new features, improvements to the compiler, and better conformance to the ANSI standard. Notable changes include an overhaul of thread synchronization primitives, better unicode support, and preliminary support for the Emscripten target. The release is available for download as a source code archive.

item.title: Scammers can exploit email forwarding flaws to impersonate high-profile domains (today.ucsd.edu)
item.description: Email Forwarding Flaws Enable Scammers to Impersonate High-Profile Domains
item.content:encoded:
Email forwarding flaws allow scammers to impersonate high-profile domains, including government organizations, financial service companies, and major news organizations. The vulnerabilities in the email forwarding process bypass the safeguards of email providers like Gmail and Outlook, making it easier for attackers to send spoofed emails containing malware or spyware. The research team discovered that many organizations outsource their email infrastructure to third-party providers, which can be exploited through email forwarding. The vulnerabilities affect a significant number of domains, including state.gov, Mastercard, The Washington Post, and the Associated Press. While some providers have patched the issues, researchers recommend disabling open forwarding and implementing stricter validation policies to enhance email security.

163 Points | 42 comments

item.title: The rxv64 Operating System: MIT's xv6, in Rust, for SMP x86_64 machines (github.com)
item.description: 'rxv64': A Pedagogical Operating System Reimplementation in Rust
item.content:encoded:
rxv64 is a pedagogical operating system written in Rust that targets multiprocessor x86_64 machines. It is a reimplementation of the xv6 operating system from MIT. The system supports very little hardware other than the text-mode CGA device, serial port, PS/2 keyboard controller, and PCIe AHCI SATA storage devices. The xv6 README provides more information on provenance and intended use.

item.title: Using LD_PRELOAD to cheat, inject features and investigate programs (rafalcieslak.wordpress.com)
item.description: Manipulating Application Behavior with LD_PRELOAD: Fun and Useful Tricks in Linux
item.content:encoded:
Using LD_PRELOAD to manipulate the behavior of applications without modifying their source code or recompiling them is a powerful trick in Linux. This technique allows users to inject custom code into applications transparently, such as modifying the behavior of the random number generator or intercepting file access calls. The blog post provides examples of how LD_PRELOAD can be used to cheat in games, investigate unknown applications by monitoring file I/O and internet access, and even create bullet-time effects in games. The author emphasizes that while this trick can be fun and useful for debugging, it should not be used to bypass security or gain root privileges.

128 Points | 70 comments

item.title: Ruby Outperforms C: Breaking the Catch-22 (railsatscale.com)
item.description: 'YJIT and Pure Ruby Implementation Outperform C Extension in Ruby Performance Optimization'
item.content:encoded:
The article discusses the performance optimization of Ruby code by comparing it with C extensions. It presents a benchmark test of parsing GraphQL queries using the GraphQL Ruby gem and the Racc C extension. The results show that YJIT, a just-in-time compiler, can outperform the C extension when used with the pure Ruby implementation of Racc. The article also introduces TinyGQL, a pure Ruby GraphQL parser, which achieves faster performance than the C extension when combined with YJIT.

The code includes functions for initializing the grid, updating the grid based on the rules of the game, and rendering the grid. It also includes helper functions for counting the number of live neighbors for each cell and checking if a cell is alive or dead. Overall, this file seems to be a self-contained implementation of the game of life in TypeScript.

item.title: X challenges California’s new transparency law as unconstitutional (techcrunch.com)
item.description: 'X' Challenges California's New Transparency Law as Unconstitutional
item.content:encoded:
X, formerly known as Twitter, has filed a lawsuit challenging a new California law that requires social media companies to disclose their moderation practices. The law aims to bring transparency and accountability to social media content, but X argues that it violates their Constitutional right to free speech. The lawsuit claims that the law is a form of compelled speech and an unconstitutional government overreach. The outcome of the lawsuit will have implications for the balance between government involvement and private platform moderation practices.

5 Points | 1 comments

item.title: Maybe Rust isn’t a good tool for massively concurrent, userspace software (bitbashing.io)
item.description: The Challenges of Using Async Rust for Concurrency
item.content:encoded:
The article discusses the challenges and limitations of using async Rust for concurrency. It explains the difference between parallelism and concurrency and how breaking a problem into separate, independent parts can improve performance. The author highlights the drawbacks of using threads and mutex-based concurrency, such as race conditions and deadlocks. They introduce the concept of channels as a synchronization mechanism and discuss how many modern languages provide channels in their standard libraries. The article then delves into the complexities of async Rust, including the tension between low-level control and the need for dynamic lifetimes. It concludes by suggesting that Rust may not be the best tool for massively concurrent, userspace software.

581 Points | 480 comments

item.title: Cisco Systems and Financialization (www.ineteconomics.org)
item.description: Cisco Systems' Financialization and its Impact on the US Technology Industry
item.content:encoded:
Cisco Systems, once a global leader in telecommunication systems and the Internet, has fallen behind global competitors in critical technologies such as 5G and Internet of Things (IoT). This is due to the company's shift from innovation to financialization, prioritizing stock buybacks to boost its stock price instead of investing in cutting-edge communication-infrastructure products. Since 2001, Cisco has spent $152.3 billion on stock buybacks, wasting funds that could have been used for innovation. The company's turn from innovation to financialization has implications for the competitive position of the US information-and-communication-technology industry. This article provides an in-depth analysis of Cisco's organizational failure and its impact on the US technology industry.

35 Points | 28 comments

item.title: Just how constexpr is C++20’s std:string? (quuxplusone.github.io)
item.description: Understanding the Constraints of C++20's constexpr std::string and std::vector
item.content:encoded:
C++20's std::string and std::vector can be marked as constexpr, allowing them to be used in compile-time programming. However, there are two constraints on constexprness: the value cannot depend on any runtime input, and certain data cannot flow from compile-time into runtime. The article explains these constraints in detail and provides examples. It also discusses the subtleties of using string and vector in constexpr, such as the impact of small string optimization (SSO) and pointers to self. The article concludes that while constexpr string and vector can be used, it is generally recommended to use them as local variables or return types of constexpr or consteval functions rather than as constexpr or constinit variables.

106 Points | 84 comments

item.title: SoftGPU: SW and HW accelerated driver for Windows 9x Virtual Machines (github.com)
item.description: SoftGPU: Software and Hardware Accelerated Drivers for Windows 9x Virtual Machines
item.content:encoded:
SoftGPU is a compilation of four projects that provide software and hardware accelerated drivers for Windows 9x virtual machines. It requires a virtual machine with VGA adapter support and Windows 95/98/Me as the guest system. The compilation includes the necessary DirectX versions, Visual C runtime, and OpenGL 95. SoftGPU offers three render drivers: softpipe, llvmlipe, and SVGA3D. The performance of these renderers varies, with SVGA3D providing the highest expected FPS. The hypervisor translation to real hardware GPU is also discussed. The installation process and system requirements are outlined, along with instructions for setting up a VirtualBox VM with hardware acceleration. The article concludes with information on running DirectX tests and optimizing performance for newer CPUs.

33 Points | 1 comments

item.title: FTC judge rules Intuit broke law, must stop advertising TurboTax as “free” (arstechnica.com)
item.description: FTC Judge Rules Intuit Must Stop Advertising TurboTax as 'Free'
item.content:encoded:
Intuit, the company behind TurboTax, has been ruled by a Federal Trade Commission (FTC) judge to have violated US law with deceptive advertising. The judge stated that Intuit must stop promoting TurboTax as 'free' unless all conditions of the free offer are clearly displayed to consumers. Intuit plans to appeal the decision and criticized the FTC's 'predetermined decision.' The ruling comes after the FTC filed an administrative complaint against Intuit in March 2022. If the ruling survives appeal, the order will be in effect for 20 years. Intuit has already agreed to pay $141 million in restitution to consumers in a separate case involving all 50 US states and the District of Columbia.

133 Points | 21 comments
